data.title: Why the colon?
data.body:
Testing #9684

Each variable page group seems to end with the colon `:`, as if there is a value right after it.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/22350/17137952/3a8904f0-533e-11e6-8dc4-a1e953b45a0e.png)

But there never is ðŸ˜¢

data.title: Variable paging still faces performance issues
data.body:
Testing #9684

```
const arr = new Array(Math.pow(10, 9));
console.log(arr);
```
1. Set breakpoint on line `2`.
2. Start debug
3. Expand the `arr` local variable

VS Code will eventually crash. This happens because, I'm guessing, the tree will show `10^7` items in the tree, since the page size is fixed to 100.

Pages should be recursive. Expanding `arr`, in this case, should show a set maximum number of pages (eg 1000); and each page, when expanded, would contain further pages. Eg:
- `[0...10000]`
  - `[0...100]`
    - `0`
    - `1`
    - ...
  - `[100...200]`
    - `100`
    - `101`
    - ...
  - ...
- ...

data.title: Add keyboard shortcut to select word
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version:Win 7 x64

Please, add option to select word where the cursor is. I couldn't find it in the shortcuts list here.
For example, in VS it's `ctrl+w`.

data.title: Force textEditor options for language types
data.body:
Hello - I have another question here.

Due to parser limitation, some documents I'm analyzing should have a default tab size and tab for indent.

I've looked into the API, but I do not find anyway to specify those options as default when working with documents in editor when `languageId === myThing`

I was thinking about hooking on `window.onChangeActiveTextEditor` but at first that would change the options every time and also it seems like `textEditor.options` are read only (or changes are not propagated)

Where should I look into? Is it possible to specify default options in contributions point probably?

Thanks a lot again,
V.

data.title: Can't expand array in watch expressions & repl
data.body:
Testing #9684

``` es6
const arr = new Array(10000);
console.log(arr);
```
1. Set breakpoint on line `2`.
2. Add `arr` watch expression.
3. Start debug

Can't expand the `arr` watch expression when paused in the breakpoint. Also can't expand the same expression in the repl.

data.title: Cannot use message service before workbench is up
Allow to select text while jumping between brackets

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: Win 7 x64

For me, the default shortcut for jumping to matching bracket was `ctrl+shift+\`
I changed it to `ctrl+]`  and while holding down shift, I expect it to select the text from bracket to bracket. I believe that this is a reasonable request as this behaviour can be seen in many other text editors.

Thanks! 
Also just want to thank you for doing this, I love this editor!

data.title: Got stuck in `Tab moves focus` mode
data.body:
Steps to Reproduce:
1. Have a 2 pane layout.
2. Hit <kbd>Cmd ,</kbd> to open user settings.
3. Hit <kbd>Cmd 1</kbd> to focus the first pane.
4. Use quick open to switch to an editable file.
5. Hit <kbd>Cmd 2</kbd> to focus the user settings and make any **valid** change there.
6. Hit <kbd>Cmd 1</kbd> to focus the first pane.

<kbd>Tab</kbd> will now focus away from the editor instead of inserting a `TAB`.

data.title: Quick open perf: no immediate reponse when deleting characters
data.body:
refs: #9700

win / insiders
1. open node workspace, ctrl + p, input: 'abcdefg'
2. hold the backspace key and delete all the keys - notice how this is not smooth
3. I guess this is due to the fact that we are optimizing for users adding keys, not deleting them

data.title: [tab completion] multi cursor behaviour different to emmet
data.body:
Testing #9698: - enable tab completion: `"editor.tabCompletion": true` - create a html snippet ``` json "Div": { "prefix": "div", "body": [ "
", " ${}", "
" ], "description": "New div" } ``` - in a html file have a multiple lines with content 'div'. Set multiple cursors after each div. Press tab. ðŸ‘‰ primary div is expanded - do the same with multiple lines of span, press tab ðŸ‘‰ tab character is added at each of the cursors Not sure if the emmet behaviour is intentional. It would be cool if the expansion happens on every cursor.

data.title: Terminal copy / paste shortucts make a confusing user experience
data.body:
Refs: #9100
1. `ctrl + shift + c`, and `ctrl + shift + v` are copy / paste when terminal has focus
2. these keybindings do some completly different actions when terminal does not have focus. Both these actions are 'heavy', opening preview and opening a terminal outside of vscode
3. While I tested the copy / paste feature I accidently triggered the other actions multiple times and this led to a very frustrating experience

My suggestions is that these actions should be disabled when terminal is visible. Not when terminal has focus, imho that is the biggest flow of the current approach. If these actions were enabled when terminal is visible they could also be exectued from the command palette (my concers around this are raised in other bugs).

data.title: [tab completion] Don't complete if selection is not empty
data.body:
Testing #9698: - enable tab completion: `"editor.tabCompletion": true` - create a html snippet ``` json "Div": { "prefix": "div", "body": [ "
", " ${}", "
" ], "description": "New div" } ``` - in a html file have a line with content 'div', select the whole line from left to right, press tab -> div is expanded. I would expect it to be indented. IMO we should only do tab completion on an empty selection, so that it's also possible to indent a line.

data.title: 'Terminal: Copy Selection' no way to be executed from the command palette
data.body:
Refs: #9100 

Linux, insiders
1. Try to execute the command 'Terminal: Copy Selection' from the command palette
2. There is no way to do this, since when the command palette has focus the terminal does not and the action will complain
3. I would expect the action to still work, or to not be present in the command palette

This action and the paste into intregrated terminal do not feel like global workbench actions to me. Due to this and #9760 I propose to remove them from the command pallete. If there is no mechanism for global workbench actions to be omitted from the command pallete we should introduce one, since these actions should not be in the command pallete imho

data.title: Paste into active terminal pastes into editor instead
data.body:
Refs: #9100

Linux, insiders
1. Have some text in your clipboard
2. Execute workbench command 'paste into active terminal', notice how the text gets pasted into the editor instead of the terminal

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.3.1 (e6b4afa53e9c0f54edef1673de9001e9f0f547ae, 2016-07-12T13:35:06.227Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.10586

Steps to Reproduce:
1. open any makefile
2. add

```
define defined
    $(info Checkng existance of $(1))
    $(if ifeq "$(flavor $(1))" "undefined",0,1)
endef
```

BEFORE some random lines with syntax highlighted expected
3. Look at syntax highlighting from $(1)) "undefined" onwards

Same also proves true for the origin variant of flavor
Here is an example
[paths.mk.txt](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/383477/paths.mk.txt)

data.title: [terminal] Popups shown for each command executed
data.body:
Elementary OS, Freya

Every time I execute a command in the terminal, the OS shows a popup that the task has completed. That doesn't happen when I do the same in the OS'es terminal, or with other commands that VSCode runs internally.

![command-popups2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6461412/17132399/de732342-5321-11e6-9d97-f3862930ae4a.gif)

data.title: Breakpoints disappear when a file is modified outside current workspace

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Testing #9533
- VSCode Version: Latest insiders
- OS Version: OSX

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  Enable a breakpoint on a file and start debug session
2.  Make sure this break point is hit during debugging
3. Modify the file outside - I used a different VS Code (stable) to edit
4. Notice that file gets updates in current workspace - Good

Observed:
- Existing break point disappeared
- Continuing debugging, break point is hit even though it is not appearing

Expected
- Existing break point should be unverified

data.title: Terminal lacks focus indication
data.body:
Testing #9695

Through two separate situations, I've been able to get into a state in which the terminal lacks focus indication through the cursor:
- Simply disable cursor blinking (related to #9753). When moving focus to the editor and back to the terminal, there is no indication that the terminal has focus at all.
- Or, leave the blinking cursor, run the `htop` command, exit it with <kbd>Q</kbd> and the terminal will then lack focus information when moving focus to the editor and back again.

data.title: Default terminal cursor should not blink
data.body:
Testing #9695

Usually terminals don't have a blinking cursor by default, I suggest we set it to false. The cursor should then be the _filled_ rectangle.

data.title: number/boolean values not working
data.body:
re #9560

```
{
    "command": "echo",
    "isShellCommand": true,
    "args": ["Hello World", "${workspaceRoot}", "${config.editor.lineNumber}"],
    "showOutput": "always",
    "version": "0.1.0"
}
```
- have a `task.json` like above
- the value of `editor.lineNumber` isn't interpreted, the same for `boolean` values

I'd expect that I can use primitive values like `boolean` and `number` in addition to `string`. Maybe even arrays.

data.title: Unable to select a desired keyboard shortcut due to keyboard layout
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.3.1 (1.3.1)
- OS Version: 10.10.5 (14F1808)

Steps to Reproduce:
- Have a French Canadian keyboard
- Go to Preferences > Keyboard Shortcuts
- Look for this shortcut:

```
{ "key": "cmd+/",                 "command": "editor.action.commentLine",
                                             "when": "editorTextFocus" }
```
- Try to use the desired shortcut (`cmd + /`), shortcut doesn't work because keyboard layout takes precedence over actual keycode.

I am trying to change the "editor.action.commentLine", however the keys are already appropriate. Upon further investigation, the editor detects my keyboard (French Canadian) and forces "âŒ˜+Ã©" rather than the displayed (and desired) "âŒ˜+/"

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1410355/17131893/a9477b70-531f-11e6-93df-64df70ff62af.png)

How can I force the editor to use "âŒ˜+/" instead? The "Ã©" key is totally not what I want to use, and if I type "/", no change occurs. Is there a way to force the use of a keycode rather than the character the key types?

data.title: Improve the debian package metadata
data.body:
When in Elementary OS (and Ubuntu too), double clicking the deb package opens this window:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/22350/17131785/5881e540-531f-11e6-8d0e-8c88a124a079.png)

We should improve this:
- Set a better label for the title: `VS Code Insiders`
- The `https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/setup/linux` link in the description can't be clicked. Maybe we should remove it and add it some other way, like the `Developer Web Site` link is set.
- Include our icon
- Include a screenshot
- Add out license, instead of leaving it `Unknown`

data.title: Make new break points unverified on a file which is updated during debug session
data.body:
Testing #9533
- VSCode Version: latest insiders
- OS Version: OSX

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  Enable a break point on a file and start the debug session
2. During the debug session, modify the fie
3. Note that existing break points are unverified - Good
4. Put a new break point in the file

Expected
- New break point has to be in unverified state

Actual
- New break point is active

data.title: [terminal] Support Ctrl+C/Ctrl+V shortcuts
data.body:
Testing #9723:

With copy/paste in the context menu, I expect also the copy/paste shortcuts to work.
I suggest to copy if there is a selection and send the Ctrl-C sequence to the terminal if there is no selection.
